training_organizations.name: North Carolina DSS Child Welfare Services Staff Development
training_organizations.description: North Carolina’s Division of Social Services, in collaboration with UNC Chapel Hill, provides training and staff development for the state’s county child welfare agencies. This includes the Child Welfare Collaborative (a IV-E student training program) and the NC Child Welfare Education System which delivers standardized training to all new county CPS workers on core skills, as well as advanced courses. The goal is to ensure consistency across NC’s 100 counties.

training_organizations.name: Children’s Home Society of North Carolina
training_organizations.description: A statewide nonprofit that partners closely with NC’s child welfare system. Children’s Home Society (CHS) holds contracts to deliver key services: it recruits and trains foster and adoptive parents for many counties, provides intensive family preservation programs to prevent foster care entries, and runs adoption promotion programs to find permanent families for youth. CHS essentially extends DSS’s reach by providing these operational supports for foster care and family services.

training_organizations.name: ACTION for Child Protection
training_organizations.description: A nonprofit organization that has provided consultation and training on CPS best practices to North Carolina. ACTION for Child Protection specializes in safety assessment and planning; NC DSS worked with ACTION when implementing its multiple response system and structured intake process. Through this partnership, NC incorporated evidence-based safety decision-making approaches, improving how social workers assess risks and create safety plans to protect children.

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.InvestQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.DecentralScreen: Each county/region has own screening unit
policies.ScreenerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: Illegal placement or adoption; Refusal to follow recommendations of the Juvenile and Family Team
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes physical injury, cruel/grossly inappropriate behavior modification, sexual abuse, emotional abuse, moral turpitude, and human trafficking
policies.CaseManagerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes improper care, improper supervision, improper discipline, abandonment, improper medical/remedial care, injurious environment, human trafficking, illegal placement or adoption, refusal to follow recommendation of Juvenile and Family Team
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: A Human Services Program Consultant is dedicated to working on DEI in child welfare
policies.DecentralizedReporting: Each county/region has own reporting hotline
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Referral for early intervention services; Referral for early investigation services
policies.ScreenReq_OtherSpecify: Determine the county responsible for completing the Child Protective Services (CPS) assessment
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: Information to identify and locate the child(ren), parents, or primary caretaker; Assess the seriousness of the child's situation; Understand the relationship of the reporter to the family and the motives of the reporter
policies.EquityStaff_OtherSpecify: Maintain communication with DSS Child Welfare Leadership in building the framework for DEI work; Assist in the development of DEI training for state and county staff; Facilitate meetings with NCDHHS DSS Child Welfare DEI Team; Monitor and ensure the Child Welfare DEI Action Plan; Participate in developing child welfare training to ensure that a racial lens is present; Manage Racial Equity contracts with vendors; Attend trainings that focuses on DEI in Child Welfare, Education, Juvenile Justice, Health, Mental Health, etc.; Continue to monitor state and county child welfare data (disproportionality and disparity)
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For human trafficking, the perpetrator can be any person
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: A minimum of 72 hours of preservice training, plus additional training (minimum of 18 hours for child welfare workers and 54 hours for supervisors) as needed; Training requirements may be waived if workers have (1) completed or are enrolled in a bachelor's or master's program after July 1, 1999 or (2) have child welfare experience in another state and have completed child welfare training equivalent to the training in this state
policies.AltResp_Inelig_OtherSpecify: The suspected or confirmed presence of a methamphetamine lab where children are exposed; A child less than a year who has been shaken or subjected to spanking, hitting, or other form of corporal punishment; The child or youth is believed to be the victim of human trafficking
policies.InvestReq_OtherCases_Specify: Referral for early intervention services whenever there is a concern regarding a child's development, or within 72 hours of a case decision for children identified as substance affected infants or who are involved in a substantiated case of abuse, neglect and/or dependency or found in need of services; Referral for early investigation services for children identified as substance affected infants or who are involved in a substantiated case of abuse, neglect and/or dependency or found in need of services must be screened for referral to the NC Infant Toddler Program for early intervention services or children with developmental delay
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: A minimum of 72 hours of preservice training, plus additional training (minimum of 18 hours for child welfare workers and 54 hours for supervisors) as needed; Training requirements may be waived if workers have (1) completed or are enrolled in a bachelor's or master's program after July 1, 1999 or (2) have child welfare experience in another state and have completed child welfare training equivalent to the training in this state
policies.InvestReq_MHEvalCases_Specify: Physical abuse; Sexual abuse; Neglect; Emotional abuse
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Required for the following: (1) children under the age of 1 or are pre-cruising with a sentinel injury, (2) children 3 years-old and under; that are non-verbal; or that appear developmentally delayed; who have or have concerns for abusive head trauma, bruises, head injuries, intentional or poorly/unexplained burns, inflicted or poorly/unexplained fractures, maltreatment because their sibling suffered a near fatality, hospitalized for maltreatment, malnutrition or failure to thrive, medical neglect, sexual abuse, (3) children 3 years-old and under; that are non-verbal; or that appear developmentally delayed; who live with a child that has, during the current CPS assessment obtained serious injuries, died from suspected abuse/neglect, placed out of home due to physical or sexual abuse, or tested positive for a sexually transmitted infection, (4) any child that has suffered a near fatality, (5) children 4 years old and older with allegations of abusive head trauma, bruises, head injuries, intentional or poorly/unexplained burns, inflicted or poorly/unexplained fractures, hospitalized for maltreatment, malnutrition or failure to thrive, medical child abuse, medical neglect, sexual abuse
policies.AltResp_EligibilityMaltreatment: Only certain types of maltreatment are eligible
policies.CaseManagerQual_TrainingSpecify: A minimum of 72 hours of preservice training, plus additional training (minimum of 18 hours for child welfare workers and 54 hours for supervisors) as needed; Foster care workers must complete a minimum of 39 hours of additional training; Training requirements may be waived if workers have (1) completed or are enrolled in a bachelor's or master's program after July 1, 1999 or (2) have child welfare experience in another state and have completed child welfare training equivalent to the training in this state
policies.AltResp_Eligibility_OtherSpecify: (1) Not in custody of county child welfare agency residing in family foster homes or residential facilities, (2) a child was not taken into protective custody by physician or law enforcement, (3) a child was not hospitalized (admitted to hospital) due to suspected abuse and/or neglect, (4) not a medically neglected disabled infant with a life-threatening condition, (5) not a sibling of a family with a child fatality
policies.ReligiousObjections_OtherSpecify: There are no laws allowing private child placing agencies to withhold serving certain children of families due to religious objections, however, private child placing agencies do not have to accept a placement and do not have to provide a reason
